001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004
005/**
006 * A specialized StatefulRandomness that produces a pre-determined sequence of results as {@link #nextLong()}
007 * and/or {@link #next(int)} are called. This is meant for testing corner-case bugs in any kind of procedural
008 * generation, where certain, possibly very rare, number sequences at points in a program cause issues.
009 * Rather than rely on finding a seed that, at just the right point in its sequence, causes such a problem,
010 * you can use a SpecifiedRandomness that could cause the problem right away so it can be debugged.
011 * <br>
012 * The idea for this came from GoRogue and its
013 * <a href="https://github.com/Chris3606/GoRogue/blob/master/GoRogue/Random/KnownSeriesRandom.cs">KnownSeriesRandom</a>
014 * class. Thanks Chris3606!
015 */
016public class SpecifiedRandomness implements StatefulRandomness, Serializable {
017    private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
018
019    public long state;
020    public long[] results;
021
022    /**
023     * Constructs a SpecifiedRandomness that will produce the sequence:
024     * {@code -1, 0, 9223372036854775807, -9223372036854775808}
025     * in a cycle.
026     */
027    public SpecifiedRandomness() {
028        state = 0L;
029        results = new long[]{-1L, 0L, Long.MAX_VALUE, Long.MIN_VALUE};
030    }
031
032    /**
033     * Constructs a SpecifiedRandomness given a non-null, non-empty array or vararg of long results.
034     * This array or vararg will be the sequence this produces.
035     * @param results a non-null, non-empty array or vararg of long to use as the sequence this produces
036     */
037    public SpecifiedRandomness(long... results) {
038        state = 0L;
039        this.results = results == null || results.length == 0
040                ? new long[]{-1L, 0L, Long.MAX_VALUE, Long.MIN_VALUE} : results;
041    }
042
043    /**
044     * Copies the given SpecifiedRandomness into a new one, using the same state and results sequence.
045     * @param other another, non-null, SpecifiedRandomness to deep-copy into this
046     */
047    public SpecifiedRandomness(SpecifiedRandomness other) {
048        state = other.state;
049        results = new long[other.results.length];
050        System.arraycopy(other.results, 0, results, 0, results.length);
051    }
052
053    /**
054     * Using this method, any algorithm that might use the built-in Java Random
055     * can interface with this randomness source.
056     *
057     * @param bits the number of bits to be returned
058     * @return the integer containing the appropriate number of bits
059     */
060    @Override
061    public int next(int bits) {
062        return (int) results[(int) (state++ & 0x7FFFFFFFL) % results.length] & (-1 >>> 32 - bits);
063    }
064
065    /**
066     * Using this method, any algorithm that needs to efficiently generate more
067     * than 32 bits of random data can interface with this randomness source.
068     * <p>
069     * Get a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).
070     *
071     * @return a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive)
072     */
073    @Override
074    public long nextLong() {
075        return results[(int) (state++ & 0x7FFFFFFFL) % results.length];
076    }
077
078    /**
079     * Get the current internal state of the StatefulRandomness as a long.
080     *
081     * @return the current internal state of this object.
082     */
083    @Override
084    public long getState() {
085        return state;
086    }
087
088    /**
089     * Set the current internal state of this StatefulRandomness with a long.
090     *
091     * @param state any 64-bit long.
092     */
093    @Override
094    public void setState(long state) {
095        this.state = state;
096    }
097
098    /**
099     * Produces a copy of this SpecifiedRandomness that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the
100     * copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just needs to
101     * copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
102     *
103     * @return a copy of this SpecifiedRandomness
104     */
105    @Override
106    public SpecifiedRandomness copy() {
107        return new SpecifiedRandomness(this);
108    }
109}
